column3: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/22f0135df0f6ee94c137d6c59209bdfbd93533fc for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu

NACK

The term "core" should be used with respect to the consensus-critical part, not all the extra wallet code, relay code, and so on that the reference implementation adds. We need a shorter term than "reference implementation" however.
@petertodd this discussion has been done a long time ago, please only ACK/NACK based on the code and not the naming.\n
@laanwj Oh it has? I've been out of the country. Disregard my comment then.\n

See for example https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/3203 but it goes much further back, I can't find the original issue right now. \n\nThe point is that we don't want the client to be called "Bitcoin" anymore to remove confusion between the software and the network. There were several suggestions for names but at a certain point it was settled at "Bitcoin Core" (just too much shed painting I

Well mainly I was thinking in terms of how at the Dark Wallet hackathon I convinced Amir and others that creating a stand-alone "consensus core" library was a good idea - naturally calling it libbitcoinconsensuscore or something equally unwieldy makes sense. But such a library isn't really user-facing anyway so if they both end up with "core" in the name it'll only confuse devs - I think we can li
